description: The Becoming a Linux Server Administrator covers managing Linux servers in a business environment. Topics covered include installing Linux as a server, managing networking and troubleshooting the OS. Other episodes demonstrate how to configure a web server, a file server, and other common servers. The primary goal of the course is to help system administrators learn to deploy and support the Linux operating system as a server platform.
descriptionMD: The *Becoming a Linux Server Administrator* covers managing Linux servers in a business environment. Topics covered include installing Linux as a server, managing networking and troubleshooting the OS. Other episodes demonstrate how to configure a web server, a file server, and other common servers. The primary goal of the course is to help system administrators learn to deploy and support the Linux operating system as a server platform.
name: Becoming a Linux Server Admin
subtitle: Becoming a Linux Server Admin

episodes.description: The Becoming a Linux Server Administrator covers managing Linux servers in a business environment. Topics covered include installing Linux as a server, managing networking and troubleshooting the OS. Other episodes demonstrate how to configure a web server, a file server, and other common servers. The primary goal of the course is to help system administrators learn to deploy and support the Linux operating system as a server platform.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.846
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.846 --> 00:00:07.169
Hello, and thank you for joining us.

3
00:00:07.169 --> 00:00:09.557
In this video we're taking
to look at the upcoming,

4
00:00:09.557 --> 00:00:12.030
Becoming a Linux Server Administrator
series.

5
00:00:12.030 --> 00:00:15.600
And what is becoming
a Linux Server Administrator series?

6
00:00:15.600 --> 00:00:18.300
>> Sure, you know a lot of people out
there wan to learn the Linux operating

7
00:00:18.300 --> 00:00:21.460
systems, it's very popular and most people
get their start working on a desktop.

8
00:00:21.460 --> 00:00:25.400
You install Linux on your laptop, or
your PC, and that's how you learn it.

9
00:00:25.400 --> 00:00:29.950
But in real life land where Linux really
dominates is in the server market.

10
00:00:29.950 --> 00:00:33.180
And you'll find that running Linux
on a server is a lot different

11
00:00:33.180 --> 00:00:35.270
than running Linux on a work station.

12
00:00:35.270 --> 00:00:38.010
So in this series what we do is we try and

13
00:00:38.010 --> 00:00:39.940
get the users accustomed
to working on a server.

14
00:00:39.940 --> 00:00:40.990
We show them that environment,

15
00:00:40.990 --> 00:00:44.110
what it's like working with Linux in
a server environment and the different

16
00:00:44.110 --> 00:00:47.580
administrative tasks we have to perform
to keep that system up and running.

17
00:00:47.580 --> 00:00:51.620
It really helps to take your Linux skills
from hobbyist to professional, and

18
00:00:51.620 --> 00:00:55.230
get you out there in the real world using
trade skills to manage Linux servers.

19
00:00:55.230 --> 00:00:57.190
>> And who is the show targeted towards?

20
00:00:57.190 --> 00:00:59.840
>> Well, this could really apply
to a number of different people,

21
00:00:59.840 --> 00:01:03.530
if you work for a company that implements
Linux servers and you're responsible for

22
00:01:03.530 --> 00:01:06.130
supporting those servers this
series should be great for you.

23
00:01:06.130 --> 00:01:09.120
Cuz we're gonna help you ensure those
servers are installed properly.

24
00:01:09.120 --> 00:01:10.240
And show you how to maintain them.

25
00:01:10.240 --> 00:01:12.420
And run the different services
that are inside of there.

26
00:01:12.420 --> 00:01:14.630
If you're just curious about
how Linux servers work,

27
00:01:14.630 --> 00:01:16.780
this is a great series for you.

28
00:01:16.780 --> 00:01:18.920
But if you're looking to
run Linux on your desktop,

29
00:01:18.920 --> 00:01:22.310
well that's not really a thing
we're going to be covering here.

30
00:01:22.310 --> 00:01:25.450
In fact, we're going to do very very
little with the graphical user interface.

31
00:01:25.450 --> 00:01:27.650
So if you're just getting
started with Linux,

32
00:01:27.650 --> 00:01:29.760
this will be a pretty harsh spot to start.

33
00:01:29.760 --> 00:01:32.950
So, the typical viewer for the series
is gonna be somebody who already

34
00:01:32.950 --> 00:01:34.900
has experience working with
a Linux operating system,

35
00:01:34.900 --> 00:01:37.880
maybe not servers but
at least experience with the OS itself.

36
00:01:37.880 --> 00:01:39.490
And is ready to make that jump.

37
00:01:39.490 --> 00:01:43.175
If you're somebody who's just starting
out, wanting to get that first taste

38
00:01:43.175 --> 00:01:45.675
of working with Linux,
I encourage you to check out our Linux for

39
00:01:45.675 --> 00:01:49.355
Beginners series, or
our Becoming a Linux System Administrator.

40
00:01:49.355 --> 00:01:50.565
Different than server administrator.

41
00:01:50.565 --> 00:01:52.185
System focuses on the desktop.

42
00:01:52.185 --> 00:01:55.225
We use a lot of GUI utilities and other
things there, and you get that experience.

43
00:01:55.225 --> 00:01:59.247
But this one, this series is dedicated
to that person that's got to support

44
00:01:59.247 --> 00:02:01.207
servers and work in that environment.

45
00:02:01.207 --> 00:02:03.507
>> Is there certificated available for
this?

46
00:02:03.507 --> 00:02:05.287
>> No, you know this series is
a little bit different than what we

47
00:02:05.287 --> 00:02:06.207
create normally on [INAUDIBLE] TV.

48
00:02:06.207 --> 00:02:08.527
A lot of our content is
certification based but

49
00:02:08.527 --> 00:02:11.057
here, it's more real world skills based.

50
00:02:11.057 --> 00:02:14.337
I wanna show you guys what it takes to
be able to manage these systems and

51
00:02:14.337 --> 00:02:16.657
give you more of a hands
on practical example.

52
00:02:16.657 --> 00:02:20.210
So as this series goes through, you'll
see where we're doing just examples,

53
00:02:20.210 --> 00:02:22.210
labs we're actually working
with the equipment and

54
00:02:22.210 --> 00:02:25.260
getting it set up and
using it and implementing it.

55
00:02:25.260 --> 00:02:28.810
Without having to worry about what
question is on a particular exam.

56
00:02:28.810 --> 00:02:31.085
There are some great certifications
out there if you're looking for

57
00:02:31.085 --> 00:02:34.700
Linux certifications we have several
on our own site like CompTIA Linux+.

58
00:02:34.700 --> 00:02:37.240
You can check those out and get certified.

59
00:02:37.240 --> 00:02:39.670
But if you're just looking
to get the practical skills,

60
00:02:39.670 --> 00:02:41.300
that's what this series is all about.

61
00:02:41.300 --> 00:02:43.350
>> Now what topics
are covered in this show?

62
00:02:43.350 --> 00:02:44.780
>> Well you know, we cover a big range.

63
00:02:44.780 --> 00:02:45.870
We start with the really important stuff,

64
00:02:45.870 --> 00:02:49.980
which is how you install a Linux server
and how you get it initially set up.

65
00:02:49.980 --> 00:02:52.810
There's a lot of initial configuration
you have to go through to get that Linux

66
00:02:52.810 --> 00:02:55.220
server in place and deployed correctly.

67
00:02:55.220 --> 00:02:58.530
We talked a little bit about securing and
hardening a Linux server,

68
00:02:58.530 --> 00:03:01.550
which is another really important thing
because these servers are typically

69
00:03:01.550 --> 00:03:03.740
exposed to the Internet, and
that makes them a security risk.

70
00:03:03.740 --> 00:03:06.090
So we've gotta make sure that
they're configured properly.

71
00:03:06.090 --> 00:03:09.790
After that, we're gonna break
down into individual services.

72
00:03:09.790 --> 00:03:12.030
And we'll take a look at
how to set up a web server,

73
00:03:12.030 --> 00:03:13.900
we'll talk about how to
set up a database server,

74
00:03:13.900 --> 00:03:18.830
we'll talk about how to do Samba and
file sharing, NFS, another file system.

75
00:03:18.830 --> 00:03:22.590
And so different kind of roles that
your Linux server can perform.

76
00:03:22.590 --> 00:03:26.170
Now we're gonna take a look
at these from the basics.

77
00:03:26.170 --> 00:03:27.740
Take for example a database server.

78
00:03:27.740 --> 00:03:29.720
If I wanna set up MariaDB.

79
00:03:29.720 --> 00:03:33.948
Well, we could have 100 hours of
content on how just to setup MariaDB.

80
00:03:33.948 --> 00:03:36.180
So in this series it's
more of an introduction.

81
00:03:36.180 --> 00:03:38.750
How we get the database server deployed,
how we connect to it,

82
00:03:38.750 --> 00:03:42.150
how we make sure it's secured
properly to be able to put it in use.

83
00:03:42.150 --> 00:03:46.480
But you can carry that knowledge on and go
into the more advanced courses later on to

84
00:03:46.480 --> 00:03:47.890
learn more about these
individual products.

85
00:03:47.890 --> 00:03:51.250
But here we'll look at how to set up
all these difference server types and

86
00:03:51.250 --> 00:03:52.840
get them running in
the production environment.

87
00:03:52.840 --> 00:03:53.710
>> That sounds great.

88
00:03:53.710 --> 00:03:56.910
Becoming a Linux server administrator,
if this sounds interesting to you, and I'm

89
00:03:56.910 --> 00:04:02.100
sure it does, watch all the video content
in becoming a Linux server administrator.

90
00:04:02.100 --> 00:04:03.410
Thank you for watching.

91
00:04:03.410 --> 00:04:04.326
See you soon.

92
00:04:04.326 --> 00:04:08.912
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss Installing Linux as a Server, why install it, how to install it, starting the Server, monitoring the Server, obtaining installation media, obtaining the necessary hardware, performing the install, and what you need to know when working with Red Hat 7.3 / Ubuntu / & Centos in regards to the installation of Linux as a Server.
episodes.title: Installing Linux as a Server

episodes.description: Don and Zach continue to cover Installing Linux As A Server, what kind of configuration is needed from the start, configuring the Server, Licensing, Networking, Drivers, Default Files, User Accounts, starting the Server, performing updates, and performing a reboot.
episodes.title: Installing Linux as a Server Part 2

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover what we need to do to secure the server, configuring passwords, configuring certificates, configure firewall, determine default zone, allow a standard service through firewall, adding custom services, allowing a non-standard service through firewall, configure TCP Wrappers, configure SELinux, view SELinux log, configure service related security, monitoring the Server, and performing updates.
episodes.title: Hardening a Linux Server

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what are some of the things we need to configure in SSH, SSHD, AllowUsers Policy, AllowGroups Policy, restarting SSH, using Certificates to login, generating a Public/ Private Key Pair, disabling Password Authentication on the server, changing the port in the SSHD config, allowing the port in the Firewall, and testing the connection.
episodes.title: Configuring SSH

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover basic log messages from boot-up, system log, SYSLOG, system log rotation, additional maintenance of logs, remote system logs, RSYSLOG, making logs permanent, SystemD Jounal, storing logs as secured binary so they can't be altered, how logging differs on various OS, persistent storage, JournalCTL command, JournalD as a replacement for SYSLOG, filtering for priority and filtering for time.
episodes.title: Configuring System Logging

episodes.description: Don and Zach consider how best to monitor performance, when we would need to view performance, viewing current & short-term data, display processes in real-time, disk storage/utilization, memory utilization/historical data, what SAR is, SYSSTAT, how we view logged CPU usage data, viewing logged disk activity, viewing logged network activity, viewing network errors, and viewing real-time data.
episodes.title: Monitoring Performance

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss options in regards to configuring networking, restarting network service, SYSTEMCTL, configuring adapters, configuration using interface scripts, SYSCONFIG, configuration using global settings, configurations that apply to all NICs, name lookups, NetworkManager (NMCLI), and configuring using NetworkManager.
episodes.title: Configure Networking

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what advanced networking is, how we begin the process, IP address Aliases, what 'Onparent' is, ethernet channel bonding, creating the bond configuration, adding the NICs to the bond, enabling the bonding module, and custom routes.
episodes.title: Advanced Networking

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what SysV Init & Upstart Init are, a brief history of SysV Init and Upstart, Upstart as improved SysV, how to manage SysV & Upstart, configuring both, how we interact with init, how init varies between distros, changing the run level while the system is running, information gathering, and manually controlling the services.
episodes.title: SysV Init and Upstart

episodes.description: Don and Zach give an overview as to why we would choose systemd over Upstart & SysV Init, go over key terms, discuss Target, NFS, go over Process, managing services, tools we need for systemd, managing run levels, and system power.
episodes.title: systemd

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what BIND is, why we would choose BIND over other DNS servers, installing the BIND packages, editing the configuration file, define the listen ports, restrict recursive lookups, verify Configuration files, cleanup permissions, named.servce, and allowing BIND through firewalld.
episodes.title: Installing BIND

episodes.description: Don and Zach explain getting started with Forward Lookup Zones, creating a Zone File, creating Core Records, what SOA is, Name Servers (NS), adding the Zone to BIND, Verify Syntax, and Cleanup Permissions.
episodes.title: Configuring Zones and Records

episodes.description: Don and Zach continue looking at Configuring Zones & Records, Reverse Lookup Records, creating Core Records, SOA, NS, Creating PTR Records, adding Zone to BIND, verify Syntax, Cleanup File Permissions, and restarting BIND.
episodes.title: Configuring Zones and Records Part 2

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss  DHCPD, standards based DHCP server, installation, minimum configuration needed to get started, configuring static DHCP leases, operations, troubleshoot fail to start, and tools for monitoring DHCP.
episodes.title: Installing dhcpd

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what software is needed, installing a minimal Apache web server, installing a 'feature rich' Apache web server, and the minimum configuration needed to get started.
episodes.title: Installing httpd

episodes.description: Don and Zach continue installing httpd, loading custom content, typical server configuration, troubleshoot fail to start after modifying configuration, storing content elsewhere, hosting multiple websites on same server, and name-based virtual hosts.
episodes.title: Installing httpd Part 2

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss SSL, if SSL is supported by default, installing SSL, generating our own certificates, define the certificate & key, multiple websites needing different certificates, and SSL versions that are compromised or weak.
episodes.title: Configuring SSL

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what MariaDB is, how to install, basic security settings, critical configuration options, getting the server on-line, and adding additional users to the server.
episodes.title: Installing MariaDB

episodes.description: Don and Zach continue the discussion on using MariaDB, updating user privileges, adding user permissions, removing user permissions, grant full access, lift user access, backup database, and restore database.
episodes.title: Installing MariaDB Part 2

episodes.description: "Don and Zach explain commands available when working with database data, creating a table, creating a database, enforcing 'uniqueness,' getting data into the table, and importing bulk data from CSV file."
episodes.title: Working with Data

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss importing data via an SQL script, getting data loaded, looking at the data, view all data in a table, changing data, and joining results from multiple tables.
episodes.title: Working with Data Part 2

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover what is needed to get Samba installed, installing Samba, configuration files, configuring Samba, using 'Testparm' to verify config file, starting/stopping Samba Daemon (SMBD), starting/stopping NetBIOS Name Server (NMBD), and allowing access through the firewall.
episodes.title: Installing Samba

episodes.description: Don and Zach talk about practical usage of Samba, sharing folders, adding folder to Samba's config file, testing to see if the share is advertised, end user access to folder, mounting a Samba share in Linux, and using GUI.
episodes.title: Installing Samba Part 2

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover why we would use NFS instead of SAMBA, what it takes to get NFS up & running, how to share a folder via NFS, modify the firewall rules, getting a client connected to the folder, and adding to FSTAB during boot.
episodes.title: Installing NFS

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what it takes to get FTP up & running, install VSFTPD, how to configure FTP, what data users see when they connect, monitoring people's access, restricting who is allowed to use the server, SELinux interfering with VSFTP, and can we make VSFTP use encryption.
episodes.title: Configuring an FTP Server

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what it takes to get SFTP up & running, enable SSH, default configuration not ideal, access SSH Shells, FTP, update SELinux, restart SSHD, and testing out the SFTP server.
episodes.title: Configuring an SFTP Server
